resource.chars:
"unity of orangization" manifest amont these families
I have found them in two species of <u>Plumularia</u> obstained by the
dredge at Port Curtis . they were of two kinds the one attached 
to the cell of the Polype, the other to the pedicle of the ovary (f. 43.44.45)
In each species there were three processes of the former kind
two above preceeding from <sup>near</sup> that edge of the aperture which is
towards the stem - the other below fromm the front part of the base of
the cell - they were conical in the one specis - club shaped and articulated in the other, and consisted of an enternal horny membrane
open at the apex and in internal delicate membrane inclosing a
cavity all these being continuous with the corresponding parts of the
stem - At the apex of each and capable of being pressed through
the aperture lay a numbr of thread cells - with moderate pressure
the threads only of these organs were pressed out

I found the second kind of organ in the species with conical processes
It consisted of a stem proceeding from the pedicle of the ovary bearing
[text?] a series of conical bodies having the same consitution as
those just described - (fig. 45) The perfect resemblance between these and the prehensile organs of the Diphydæ cannot be over-
looked

[paragraph].66. The structure of the Generative organs is still more
instructive - In the <u>Medusæ</u> I have endeavoured to shew
that there are always proceses of the two foundation membranes
the generative elements being developed between them (f.10.11a.)
[paragraph].67.<sup>18a.26a.)</sup> In the <u>Diphydæ</u> (and as I have good reason for belieiving
in the <u>Physophoridæ</u> also the generative organ commences as
a simple process of the common tube (f.39a) and undergoing
great changes of form in the course of its development (b, c) it becomes
at last exactly similar to an ordinary natatorial organ with a sac
6
